awd_titl_txt: Greenland Ice Sheet Monitoring Network (GLISN) Operations
awd_abstract_narration: The Greenland Ice Sheet Monitoring Network (GLISN) is a broadband, multi-use seismological network, enhanced by selected geodetic observations, designed with the capability to allow researchers to understand the changes currently occurring in the Arctic, and with the operational characteristics necessary to enable response to those changes as understanding improves. GLISN was established through an international collaboration, with 10 nations coordinating their efforts to develop the current 32-station observing network during the last four years.  This project will continue operations of six key stations of the network, as well as data quality control and data-management for the network. It will also improve the telemetry capability at remote stations to maximize the scientific utility of the data, reduce data latency, and reduce logistics costs. Continued leadership by IRIS in the management and coordination of the International GLISN effort will ensure continued return of high-quality data from the full 32-station network.  Observations from the GLISN network will allow improved estimation of the Earth structure under Greenland, critical for reliable estimation, interpretation, and prediction of changes in ice mass, sea level, and the crustal stress state.  These observations will also allow greatly improved analysis of deformation within the ice sheet and at its calving margins due to processes including discrete ice-loss events, melt-water drainage, crevassing, and basal sliding. Seismic analysis provides unique information about glacier dynamics and sub-glacial geology, complementing other remote-sensing and in-situ observations.  GLISN science and outreach will leverage and enhance outreach and education programs undertaken by the IRIS Consortium and its community.

por.por_cntn:
The Greenland Ice Sheet Monitoring Network (GLISN) is an international collaboration between seismologists in the United States and ten other countries to install and operate 34 remote seismic stations across Greenland and neighboring regions of the Arctic. Launched in 2010, GLISN has dramatically improved the coverage of seismic stations in one of the most hostile polar environments on the planet. Data from GLISN stations (relayed to scientists via real-time telemetry) have informed groundbreaking research on the properties of the mantle and crust beneath Greenland, as well as the dynamic and fast-changing characteristics of the massive Greenland Ice Sheet.

 

Some of the key discoveries and accomplishments of the network include:

●       Using seismic data to track ice sheet melting rates

●       Increased understanding of ice sheet calving processes from seismic signals

●       Landslide/Tsunami hazard detection and monitoring following 2017 Nuugaatsiaq disaster

●       Revealing the path of the Iceland hotspot track beneath Greenland

 

Support from the National Science Foundation was key to building and operating 6 seismic stations that constituted the U.S. contribution to the network. Many of the seismic stations installed during the project have been adopted by the Greenland Institute of Natural Resources and will continue to provide seismic data that will be useful to scientists in Greenland and around the world for years to come. Dozens of PhD students in the United States analyzed seismic data from GLISN as part of their graduate studies, and graduate students were also provided with work-study employment opportunities supporting seismic instrumentation that was deployed in Greenland. All of the seismic data collected during the GLISN project are freely and publicly available via domestic and international data repositories.
